1661187643613249536.text:
Thread contextualizing Med-PaLM 2 v GPT-4 results reported in our paper.

Benchmarks such as MedQA (USMLE) are nice but misleading indicators of LLM performance and rigorous evaluation is necessary.

Our work is fully focussed on that and we encourage the community to do the same

1661189308827721728.text: @LiamGMcCoy thank you so much, Liam and we completely agree with the sentiment!

1661182809757687811.text:
@HarshaNori Finally, we all really appreciate the work you are doing!

It‚Äôs great that we are pushing each other as peers to excel here with immense potential for impact in the medicine and health :)

1661182125926756352.text:
@HarshaNori However, this is misleading and key gaps and limitations around factuality, safety and bias are only revealed under rigorous (human) evaluation. 

Hence the need for finetuning / specialization/ alignment to the requirements of the medical domain.

Genuinely humbled to be on this panel on LLMs in healthcare @SAILhealth today.

Folks on the panel and in the audience are luminaries who have inspired me to do what I am doing today.

Grateful to @zakkohane @arjunmanrai for the opportunity.

1656852497066016774.text:
Was a great discussion spanning several aspects of LLMs in health including importance of fine tuning, causality, scale, interpretability and most importantly evaluation, fairness and safety. 

We don't necessarily have all the answers but good that the questions are being asked.

One of AI in health's grand challenges is enabling
healthcare orgs to effectively collaborate while preserving privacy + legal reqs, in turn, allowing us to build more generalizable and fair models that work for all.
 
This work shows that this future may already be feasible!

1380500176637292549.text:

Could be an exciting direction of research for the community! https://t.co/wkwYgOp3r5

1369220867071209474.text:
@lizjosullivan @skornblith Oxford released their analysis of the NHS covid exposure notifications app. TLDR:

- ~1.7 million notifications, ~600k cases prevented
- for every 1% increase in app users, covid cases can be reduced by 2.3%
- ~6.1% of app notified individuals estimated to have later tested +ve

1369221205731897349.text:
@lizjosullivan @skornblith Preprint under review: https://t.co/rWgpb3Sz0h

1368564920955011073.text:
Really enjoyed this @MedTechatUCL session presenting some of our recent research work in medical imaging and health at @GoogleAI and the many interesting questions that came after.

Talk video at https://t.co/PgpHfl8B5Z

1367919110038777857.text:
Interesting work but don't buy the need for model saliency maps to match expert radiologist annotations. 

If models are to exceed clinician performance, they will likely need to use different (and ideally complementary) features compared to humans.

1367919410556497922.text: What we actually need are good tests/methods to determine with high fidelity whether the features used by the model are new biomarkers or spurious correlations.

1367601634402963459.text:
Nice work on the trade offs between privacy & utility/fairness in health settings.

The authors may have a different take but think this work is further evidence of the need to invest in orders of magnitude larger health datasets if we want more private & generalizable ML models.

1365194290557644800.text: @zebulgar I wonder how much of Apple‚Äôs battle with FB under the guise of privacy is actually them realizing that FB is going to be their biggest competitor in making next-gen hardware products (VR/AR/smart watch, etc) and hence trying to slow down momentum early.

1364971694927056901.text:

In addition to objective metrics, we pilot a framework for clinician/layperson eval of answers revealing key gaps in Flan-PaLM responses.

1317991149118738432.text:
Nice work improving on EfficientNets but

- All lambda (L) layers has a ~7x reduction in throughput over CNNs

- Best model wrt speed-accuracy tradeoff has only a few L layers in c4 stage of Resnet

Predict future will be such hybrids but hard to see CNNs go away completely https://t.co/DCQZQVezZ1

1658639795684515841.text:
Med-PaLM 2 builds on top of PaLM 2, the latest SOTA LLM from @GoogleAI 

We further finetune / align the model to the requirements of the medical domain and introduce ensemble refinement as a simple new prompting strategy to improve the model‚Äôs medical reasoning capabilities. https://t.co/sY8LYIuh3m

1325924843057893379.text:
Super excited about this work!

Underspecification has important implications when building AI models for healthcare and this paper has  several examples from medical imaging, EHR, genomics and even epidemiology to illustrate this.

Please give it a read!

1658639803506896897.text: We also introduce a new adversarial questions benchmark dataset designed to elicit model answers with potential for harm and bias and probe the safety and limitations of LLMs in the medical domain.

1313366891063209987.text:
Excellent overview from Nathan/Ian. If you work in AI or even just have a passing interest, well worth your time.

1658639797777469440.text:
Med-PaLM 2 approaches or exceeds SOTA on multiple medical question answering benchmarks.

In particular, it reaches a score of 86.5% on MEDQA (USMLE) dataset matching performance of expert test takers (>18% over Med-PaLM).

It also reaches a new SOTA of 81.8% on PubMedQA. https://t.co/ppuCvOuqRJ

1329960525787086848.text:
Current regulatory rules for AI in health require model weights to be frozen. Hence its important we have good evidence of model generalization before deployment for safety.

This is really nice work allowing efficient estimation of the same using a *single* fixed eval set.

1661181973635710976.text: @HarshaNori We have repeatedly stressed in our papers and any long form interviews (which allows nuance) that general purpose LLMs like PaLM and GPT have strong medical knowledge encoded in them and thus exhibit strong performance on knowledge benchmarks such as MedQA (USMLE).
